topic.title: Changing the Look of Documents in Author Mode Using the Styles Menu

body.p: The Author mode renders the content of the XML documents visually, based on CSS stylesheets associated with the document.
The list of CSS styles that are available in the Styles menu depend on the framework (document type).

fig.title: Styles Drop-down Menu in a DITA Document

body.p: You can use the Styles drop-down menu to select a main css style that applies to the whole document and then select one or more alternate css styles that behave like layers and are merged sequentially with the main style. Each of the styles that are listed in this drop-down menu have a corresponding CSS file that defines how your documents are rendered in Author mode and in the output. Also, the selections from this drop-down menu are persistent, meaning that remembers them when subsequent documents are opened.

section.title: Main CSS Styles
section.p: The main styles are listed in the top section and each of their corresponding CSS files contain all the styles associated with the XML elements for the particular type of document. You can only select one main style at a time.

section.title: Alternate CSS Styles
section.p: The alternate styles are listed in the bottom section and their corresponding CSS files contain additional styling for certain XML elements and are merged with the selected main styles. You can select as many alternate styles as you wish (they are applied sequentially as layers). If you are unsure about how each of the styles with change the look of your documents based solely upon their name, there is no harm in selecting them to see the difference. You can simply deselect them to revert to the previous look.If you deselect the Enable multiple selection of alternate CSSs option in the CSS subtab of the Document Type configuration dialog box, the alternate styles are treated like main CSS styles and you can only select one at a time.
